identificationModule.briefTitle: Mechanisms of Benefit of IL4RA Inhibition in Aspirin-Exacerbated Respiratory Disease
identificationModule.officialTitle: Mechanisms of Benefit of IL4RA Inhibition in Aspirin-Exacerbated Respiratory Disease: MARINER

collaborators.name: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID)

descriptionModule.briefSummary: The overall aim of the study is to determine the clinical efficacy and mechanisms of action of anti-IL-4a (dupilumab) as treatment for patients with Chronic Rhinosinusitis with Nasal Polyposis (CRSwNP) and Aspirin-Exacerbated Respiratory Disease (AERD).
descriptionModule.detailedDescription: The protocol involves an 8-week study of dupilumab in patients with CRSwNP and/or AERD. Participants will have 4 total doses of dupilumab administered, with each dose administered every 2 weeks. There will be full clinical assessments and biospecimen collections at Baseline (Visit 1), Week 2 (Visit 2), and Week 8 (Visit 3).

armGroups.label: Dupilumab
armGroups.description: Subjects will receive dupilumab (300mg every-other-week for 8 weeks).

interventions.name: Dupilumab
interventions.description: 8-week trial of dupilumab (an anti-IL-4a) in patients with AERD.

primaryOutcomes.description: The nasal fluid levels of LTE4 will be measured at week 8 and will serve as a surrogate biomarker of respiratory mast cell activation or burden.

secondaryOutcomes.description: The nasal fluid levels of albumin will be measured at week 8 and serve as a surrogate biomarker of nasal epithelial cell integrity.

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Sense of smell - University of Pennsylvania Smell Identification Test (UPSIT)
secondaryOutcomes.description: Patients' sense of smell will be assessed at week 8 using the UPSIT. The UPSIT scale goes from 0 to 40, with 0 being worse (no scents identified) and 40 being best (all scents identified)
The extent of patients' nasal polyps will be assessed at week 8 using a TPS. The TPS scale goes from 0 (no polyps) to 8 (large polyps bilaterally), with 0 being best and 8 being worst.
Patients' nasal congestion will be assessed at week 8 by a PNIF. PNIF goes from 0 mL (no airflow) to 500 mL of airflow, with 0 being worst.

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Quality of life - 22-Item Sino-Nasal Outcome Test (SNOT-22)
secondaryOutcomes.description: Quality of life will be assessed at week 8 with a SNOT-22. For the SNOT-22, the scores range from 0 (no symptoms, excellent disease control) to 110 (maximum sinus symptoms, poor disease control).
Patients' lung function will be assessed at week 8 with an FEV1.
Asthma control will be measured at week 8 with an ACQ-6. For the ACQ-6, scores ranging from 0 (well-controlled) to 6 (extremely poorly-controlled). A lower score indicates better asthma control.

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Number of treatment-related adverse events (AEs) and serious adverse events (SAEs) leading to study drug discontinuation
secondaryOutcomes.description: Safety will be measured by the number of treatment-related AEs and SAEs leading to dupilumab discontinuation.

otherOutcomes.measure: Change in sense of smell - University of Pennsylvania Smell Identification Test (UPSIT)
otherOutcomes.description: Change from Visit 1 to Visit 2 and from Visit 1 to Visit 3 in UPSIT. The UPSIT scale goes from 0 to 40, with 0 being worse (no scents identified) and 40 being best (all scents identified)
otherOutcomes.timeFrame: 2 weeks (between Visit 1 and Visit 2) and 8 weeks (between Visit 1 and Visit 3)

otherOutcomes.measure: Change in Rhinoscopic Total Polyp Score (TPS)
otherOutcomes.description: Change from Visit 1 to Visit 2 and from Visit 1 to Visit 3 in TPS. The TPS scale goes from 0 (no polyps) to 8 (large polyps bilaterally), with 0 being best and 8 being worst.
otherOutcomes.timeFrame: 2 weeks (between Visit 1 and Visit 2) and 8 weeks (between Visit 1 and Visit 3)

otherOutcomes.measure: Change in Peak Nasal Inspiratory Flow (PNIF)
otherOutcomes.description: Change from Visit 1 to Visit 2 and from Visit 1 to Visit 3 in PNIF. PNIF goes from 0 mL (no airflow) to 500 mL of airflow, with 0 being worst.
otherOutcomes.timeFrame: 2 weeks (between Visit 1 and Visit 2) and 8 weeks (between Visit 1 and Visit 3)

otherOutcomes.description: Change from Visit 1 to Visit 2 and from Visit 1 to Visit 3 in SNOT-22. For the SNOT-22, the scores range from 0 (no symptoms, excellent disease control) to 110 (maximum sinus symptoms, poor disease control).
otherOutcomes.timeFrame: 2 weeks (between Visit 1 and Visit 2) and 8 weeks (between Visit 1 and Visit 3)

otherOutcomes.measure: Change in lung function - Forced Expiratory Volume 1 (FEV1)
otherOutcomes.description: Change from Visit 1 to Visit 2 and from Visit 1 to Visit 3 in FEV1.
otherOutcomes.timeFrame: 2 weeks (between Visit 1 and Visit 2) and 8 weeks (between Visit 1 and Visit 3)

otherOutcomes.measure: Change in Asthma control - Asthma Control Questionnaire-6 (ACQ-6)
otherOutcomes.description: Change from Visit 1 to Visit 2 and from Visit 1 to Visit 3 in ACQ-6. For the ACQ-6, scores ranging from 0 (well-controlled) to 6 (extremely poorly-controlled). A lower score indicates better asthma control.
otherOutcomes.timeFrame: 2 weeks (between Visit 1 and Visit 2) and 8 weeks (between Visit 1 and Visit 3)

otherOutcomes.measure: Change in Nasal fluid levels of eicosanoids
otherOutcomes.description: Change from Visit 1 to Visit 2 and from Visit 1 to Visit 3 in nasal fluid eicosanoid levels.
otherOutcomes.timeFrame: weeks (between Visit 1 and Visit 2) and 8 weeks (between Visit 1 and Visit 3)

otherOutcomes.measure: Change in Nasal fluid levels of albumin
otherOutcomes.description: Change from Visit 1 to Visit 2 and from Visit 1 to Visit 3 in nasal fluid albumin levels.
otherOutcomes.timeFrame: 2 weeks (between Visit 1 and Visit 2) and 8 weeks (between Visit 1 and Visit 3)

otherOutcomes.measure: Change in urinary levels of eicosanoids
otherOutcomes.description: Change from Visit 1 to Visit 2 and from Visit 1 to Visit 3 in urinary eicosanoid levels.
otherOutcomes.timeFrame: 2 weeks (between Visit 1 and Visit 2) and 8 weeks (between Visit 1 and Visit 3)

otherOutcomes.description: Change from Visit 1 to Visit 2 and from Visit 1 to Visit 3 in serum tryptase levels.
otherOutcomes.timeFrame: 2 weeks (between Visit 1 and Visit 2) and 8 weeks (between Visit 1 and Visit 3)

otherOutcomes.description: Change from Visit 1 to Visit 2 and from Visit 1 to Visit 3 in nasal fluid and plasma levels of IgE.
otherOutcomes.timeFrame: 2 weeks (between Visit 1 and Visit 2) and 8 weeks (between Visit 1 and Visit 3)

otherOutcomes.description: Change from Visit 1 to Visit 2 and from Visit 1 to Visit 3 in nasal fluid levels of ECP.
otherOutcomes.timeFrame: 2 weeks (between Visit 1 and Visit 2) and 8 weeks (between Visit 1 and Visit 3)

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Key Inclusion Criteria:

1. History of AERD, defined as meeting the diagnostic triad with:

   1. History of physician-diagnosed asthma and
   2. History of physician-diagnosed nasal polyposis and
   3. History of pathognomonic reactions to aspirin or other nonselective COX inhibitors.
2. Visible nasal polyps bilaterally on otoscope physical exam at the time of screening.
3. Evidence of sense of smell impairment, with a University of Pennsylvania Smell Identification Test (UPSIT) score of \<34.
4. Stable asthma (no glucocorticoid burst for at least 4 weeks prior to Visit 1, and no hospitalizations or ER visits for asthma for at least the prior 3 months).
5. Consistent (daily) use of an intranasal steroid for at least 4 weeks prior to Screening.
6. No current smoking (not more than one instance of smoking in the last 3 months).
7. For females: Practicing FDA-approved methods of birth control for the duration of the study. Female participants of childbearing potential must have a negative pregnancy test upon study entry.

Key Exclusion Criteria:

1. Use of investigational drugs within 12 weeks of Screening.
2. Use of any biologic agent within 4 months prior to Screening.
3. Use of systemic (enteral or injected) glucocorticoids within 4 weeks prior to Screening.
4. History of any sinonasal surgery within 4 months prior to Screening
5. Current use of zileuton
6. Current use of high-dose aspirin therapy (no more than 325 mg aspirin per day will be allowed)
7. Pregnant, nursing, or planning to become pregnant

Note: Other inclusion and exclusion criteria apply.

largeDocs.label: Study Protocol and Statistical Analysis Plan
